Item.Review:
Update: We've now included new info on features within the Google Nexus 7, thanks to our longer-term tests, as well as a look at how the tablet was created in just a few months. We have also added in some commentary on updates and how the tablet performs over a longer period
Undoubtedly tired of watching OEMs make little headway in their uphill struggle against Apple's iPad, Google executives took the stage at this year's Google I/O developer conference to announce a branded 7-inch tablet of their own: the Google Nexus 7 by Asus.
Like other Nexus-branded devices, the Nexus 7 tablet isn't actually hardware manufactured by Google (as you may have noticed, thanks to the suffix). As the Mountain View company has done with Samsung, HTC and Motorola in the past, it paired with Asus ... to design and manufacture its slender tablet.
It's a smart move: among Android tablets, Asus makes some of the best around, but matching the rock-bottom $199 (£125) price of Amazon's Kindle Fire while exceeding its meagre specs would be a challenge for any manufacturer.
And make no mistake: the Nexus 7 by Asus is more of an effort to stomp out Amazon's unwelcome (and forked) version of Android more than an attempt to dethrone Apple's reigning tablet champ.
The good news is that very little has been sacrificed along the way, unlike with Amazon's initial offering. According to Android boss Andy Rubin, Google's profit margin bears the brunt of any sacrifices made, from selling hardware at cost and from tossing in generous perks such as £15/$25 of Google Play credit for every Nexus 7 owner.
But enough about why and how Google and Asus have released the Nexus 7: Is it worth even £159/$199 of your hard-earned cash? expand » « collapse

Pros: Sharp Tones & Colors; Durable; Good Value; Affordable; Perfect size; Fast; Versitility; Lightweight; Long battery life; Bright
Cons: No Rear Camera; No Sd Card Slot; 16 Gb Max; No Wi-fi Cellular Model; Limited Apps
Staples shipped fast and my nexus arrived in pristine condition! Love that!
PROS: At first I didn't think I'd like the smaller size of the nexus vs the iPad, but after using it for 2 weeks I have fallen in love with the convenient 7" size! 2.The nexus is compact, sleek, and easy to carry. It fits in my purse and diaper bag much easier, 3. easy to hold for long periods of time like when watching movies, videos, or reading books. 4. The resolution is amazing and the videos come in clear, crisp and full color. Screen resolution is better tha ... n the iPad 2. 5. Easy to navigate and operate. 6. I love the more affordable price! For the amount you can do, it is definitely a great competition for the iPad which is almost twice the price. 7. Amazing battery life! I use my nexus a lot but I usually only have to charge it every other day. 8. My nexus is basically my Smartphone on Steroids! It's amazing all the additional features I have on my nexus, yet it still syncs well with my phone and appointments I make on my phone transfer to my nexus and visa versa. 9. I can do a lot of my PR work for my job on my Nexus, so I'm not always tied to a computer. I can work on the go.
CONS: 1. It does not feature the rear facing camera. I'm one of those silly people that yes, I would hold up the large block just to take a picture of my kids being silly. 2: limited upgrade capabilities. I would love to see the Nexus come out with upgrade abilities such as expandable memory, SD card slots and more. I'd love to see it with more than 16 GB 3. No Wi-fi Cellular Model. I wish I could have internet access wherever I am and not have to hunt down free wi-fi. I use the tablet for my PR website business and not having wi-fi access at my fingertips hinders me a bit with the tablet. 4. limited apps. yes, there are many apps, but we still are missing a lot of great apps that are for Apple or iOS only.
For the price, I still really love my nexus. There are only a few cons that I don't think justify spending so much more for an iPad. If you are on a budget the Nexus is definitely a great choice. expand » « collapse

Pros: Attractive design; Google play store credit; Powerful cpu and gpu; Beautiful hi res screen
Cons: Speaker; No sd card slot; Short charging cable
I purchased this tablet with the intentions to watch movies during my commute to and from work, now I find myself gaming on the tablet more than anything else.
The 7" form factor, combined with the light weight of the tablet, makes it very comfortable to hold for long preiods of time.
Screen: Video and pictures, look fantastic on the 1280x800 screen. Text is rendered very crisply, and is easy to read, w/o having to zoom in. Viewing angles are wide and splendid.
Performance: The quad core(+1) cpu, 12 core gpu, combined with android 4.1(jelly bean), offer a truly pleasant user experience, rivaling eve ... n the transformer infinity. Flicking through home screens, and widgets is seemless. Apps open very briskly, and web pgs load in a snap, thanks in part to the default chrome browser. Gaming on this tablet, has been pure bliss for me, I play gta 3, modern cambat 3, shadowgun, dead trigger, and many more titles, with nary a hiccup. Although during extended gaming, The back gets a little warm, but not hot.
Battery: After cycling the battery for the past wk, I get about 8&1/2 hrs of med to heavy use(gaming, web browsing, and video playback). Casual users will get closer to the advertised 10hrs. The tablet chargers from 3% to 100% in about 3hrs(very good).
Design/Build quality: Attractive design, Light weight, and thanks to the rubberized texture on the back, this tablet is a pleasure to hold. The volume rocker, and power button, is easy to locate, and offer nice tactile feedback.
minor(Cons): No sd card, although 16gbs is enough for me personally(most of my content is in the cloud), I think the omission is a little apple-esq on google's part. Some users report of build quality issues, including loose display panels, in fact my unit has a weak spot along the left side, but its not a deal breaker for me. The speaker on this tab is anemic, my cell phone has louder output, but with a good pair of headphones you're golden.
All in all I am very satisfied with my purchase. I plan to buy another one for my fiancee(she loves this thing), once google re-stocks the 16gb version. Props to google, for the $25 play store credit, and 4.1(jellybean). The gn7 will satisfy current android users, as well as people looking to get their feet wet, in mountain view's eco-system. Cheers. expand » « collapse

Item.ReviewTitle: Great Tablet, a few flaws, a correction
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy To Set Up; Efficient; Reliable; Easy to Use
Cons: Flimsy Construction
This tablet has a lot of great features. Of course, numero uno is bang for buck. You get a lot of features without a huge price tag. Secondly, there is a lot of content available and you can even run your apps purchased through the Amazon app store, so this is pretty much a Kindle Fire killer in my book. It's faster, has a better screen, and is pretty darned sleek.
Mine has the screen issue (the screen isn't secured properly and I have to send it back. Not a huge deal. I understand that in the tech world, there are a certain number of units that won't be perfect. Big whoop. I bought it from a Staples store and the associate literally had just got it in, so I got a big score on it! ... ). This isn't a big deal, I called Asus (the manufacturer) and it will get fixed no problem. I'm just hesitating to send it back. I love it! The screen separation isn't that bad, it makes a very faint squeaking noise when you push on the left side and when you look closely, you can see it has lifted up by about a millimeter.
As for the "flash issue," it isn't really an issue. No Jellybean phones or tablets will have Flash. Adobe is refusing to update mobile devices period. Mobile browsers are compensating by adding Flash compatibility with their browser. If the other reviewer had spent 10 minutes googling the issue, he would have realized that this is a move by Adobe, not the fault of the Andriod operating system.
Over all, if you want something cheap, efficient, fast (did I mention it's super fast?), and a lot of bang for the buck in the tablet department, the Nexus 7 is it. expand » « collapse

Pros: Reliable; Quality Construction; Easy To Set Up; Great battery life; Efficient; Easy to Use
Cons: No Card Reader; No HDMI
Great tablet. Would have given 5 stars if it had a card reader and HDMI output.

I already own a Samsung Galaxy Note and the original Asus Transformer, but playing with my partner's Acer A100, I noticed that the 7 inch form factor is really handy when you are going out and want something bigger than 5 inches, but don't want to carry a bag that fits a 10 inch tablet. First, I was thinking about just getting a cheap single-core 7 inch Chinapad, but Google's announcement of the Nexus 7 quickly changed my intentions. What really convinced me was the CPU, Jellybean and the choice of ASUS for the production, since I was already loving my TF101. So, after I got my Nexus 7, I unlocked the bootloader, rooted it and flashed the Paranoid Android rom, which I'm also using on my Galaxy Note. Paranoid Android gives you the freedom to choose the OS, as well as each application layou ... t and size individually. For example, I prefer the tablet layout with notifications on the bottom on a 7 inch tablet, but some applications are easier to use in phone layout. Other applications, like YouTube, however are simply better in their tablet layout, regardless of screen size. The performance of the Nexus 7 is very high. Everything is smooth and there is no lag whatsoever. Google Now is fun to use and Voice beats Apple's Siri in both speed and ease by far. The only thing that I'm slightly disappointed with is the battery. I'm so used to the battery performances of both my Galaxy Note and my Transformer that I expected similar performance from the Nexus 7. While the battery is still very good and beats the Acer A100 by hours(!), the Tegra 3 SoC is taking its toll on battery life. You can however tweak your CPU speed and governor settings, which can lead to longer battery life. expand » « collapse

The tablet is fast, has a sharper display than the Kindle Fire, and comes with Android 4.1 installed. The tablet comes with plenty of Google apps too -- gmail, Google Reader, Current, and more. Plus you can load up more apps with the $25 Google Play credit.
The one thing that really stands out is performance...and reliability. (ok, two things) This tablet runs circles around the Kindle Fire. It also doesn't lock up, reboot, or crash. It just works and works well.
One last thing -- th ... e 7in form factor means it can go just about anywhere. Take it to the gym, to a doctor's office, on a walk, the Nexus 7 is the perfect size. expand » « collapse

Item.ReviewTitle: How did I live without it?
Item.Review:
Pros: GPS; Good Value; Price; Light Weight Thin; Bright; Fast; Great Size; Durable
I never had a tablet - they seemed too big. This is the perfect size and with the Jelly Bean Operating System it can function very well as an informal computer. I've had mine almost a month and no problems. Add an OTG host cable, a card reader or USB, and you can download all kinds of things using Nexus Media Importer from Goole Play. Get a case to protect it and you can carry it easily in one hand like a thin book. For the price you can't beat it. With the data I use I probably would have been fine with the 8GB. Just starting to investigate all the ways to interact with it using voice. I think I've just scratched the surface of what it can do.

Item.ReviewTitle: Nexus 7 Poor quality and poor support
Item.Review: B&H Photo is an excellent vendor and nothing here should reflect badly on them. Their service is superb. The same cannot be said of ASUS, the people who manufacture the Nexus 7. Too many phone numbers and no transfer from one to another to reach Tech Support. Right out of the box the system failed to connect to my WiFi access point and would not permit any other screens. So turning to the included manual I found I needed a microscope to read the text and then I found that the text was so limited as to be useless. B&H support was very helpful and they immediately issued a return label. Bottom line, save your money and buy a Samsung Tab 2 7 inch. IMHO, it beats the Nexus hands down. That is what I will do once my refund appears.

I've been waiting to get this tablet for months and the wait was worth it. I've been using Android phones for several years, but haven't seen a tablet that has the right price mixed with great set of features. At first I was hesitant because of the 7 screen, but it is just right for doing everything. Web browsing isn't difficult or annoying and games are easy to play. The screen is perfectly responsive as well, much better than anything I've used. The speed is fantastic as well, with a the quad core tegra 3 chip this tablet is as fast as any other tablet out there. Considering it's using a vanilla Android (without any vendor added garbage) it's a perfect example of how fast an Android tablet can be. I haven't had any issues with downloaded apps either. This can be an issue on any n ... ewly released version of Android, but I've had zero problems. I would like it to have a rear-facing camera along with the front-facing, but Asus had to eliminate something to keep it price competitive. I do also miss having an SD or MiniSD slot so I can expand the storage, but again that would have added to the cost, so I can live without it. So at $250 for the 16GB, it has the absolute perfect blend of features with an excellent price. You cannot go wrong with it. expand » « collapse

I purchased this tablet on 7-12-12, B&H posted that it had an estimated 8-15 delivery date, so I didn't expect it sooner. It was a great deal with free shipping and no tax, plus Google added a $25 Google Play Store credit. The purchase was smooth and they were great about keeping me informed on the progress. I receieved it about a week sooner than expected, so a great experience with B&H. I previously purchased an Asus Transformer Prime TF201 10.2 tablet in February, so I was familiar with Android Ice Cream Sandwich. I didn't think Jelly Bean could be any faster, but I was pleasantly surprised. Very quick set up out the box, very smooth and responsive, and Google Butter makes seems to make it even smoother. I quickly customized my home screen as I didn't want the widget clutter, ... downloaded my apps and over 1000 books in my Nook and Amazon collections. This is sweet as a top of the line e-reader, as well as great for games and web-surfing. I wanted a smaller, lightweight tablet that would be easy and comfortable to hold, and easy to take places. I still have about 12gb left after all was loaded, so it looks like it will be plenty of space for my use. I am glad I got the 16gb vs. the 8gb, I think it would have filled up too fast. My only wish would have been an SD card slot for extra storage, but with the free Google cloud storage, it shouldn't be a problem. Overall a great product! expand » « collapse

Item.ReviewTitle: Dont' login if this is for a gift
Item.Review:
Cons: Inefficient; Difficult To Set Up; Flimsy Construction; Hard To Use
I bought this device for my sister. She is not familiar with computer. I charged the device and then it asked me to login to google. To test it, I followed instructions and login. I did not know that all hells would break loose for me later. This device seems to be working. So, I shipped it to my sister. When she got the device, she started to use it. However, she is not entitled the google $25 google play credit. I tried to find out why. When I contacted google, they told me that the 1st person who login would be recorded in Google cloud along with the device. No one else would the $25 credit once someone login first. It can't be undone. Now, I feel sorry about that. I won't buy anything from google ... again ever. (Consider the time and trouble I tried to locate this device from a Staples store.) expand » « collapse

Item.ReviewTitle: TOOK A CHANCE ON GOOGLE AND STAPLES
Item.Review:
Cons: Screen
I had been using my wife's Kindle Fire for over a year and was impressed with it. I thought the Nexus 7 would be a major improvement over the old Fire so I bought one through Staples - 2 major mistakes. The Nexus worked fine for 3 weeks and then developed a line across the screen which is unexpected and annoying. Also, during that time I never got that "WOW!" factor. My experience with Staples (14 day warranty period) and ASUS was expectedly disappointing. After Staples dismissed me, I was on the phone with ASUS for over 2 hours while their technically challenged "support" people tried to troubleshoot my tablet - I was even cutoff and had to call back and start over with someone else. They said to send it in for an assessment and I said "let me guess, you want me to pay ... for shipping"....correct. I hit the fan and asked for my money back and said I'll buy the new Kindle Fire. They countered with a shipping label. I'll be without a tablet for 2 weeks, when I should be enjoying a dramatically improved tablet as compared to the old Fire. I wish I would have bought the new Fire and not from Staples. If Staples cared about their customers and believed in this product they should have swapped out my tablet for a new one and dealt with ASUS on their time. expand » « collapse

Item.ReviewTitle: Good product, not as polished as iOS
Item.Review: I own both retina iPad and now Nexus 7. I really liked hte way the 7inch form factor has been implemented and the way Android is 'buttered' with Jelly Bean. The device is very powerful an battery is excellent while running graphics intensive apps like google earth, living earth etc. $25 Playstore credit was a boost for me to add several paid apps for free. Just to let you know, even to get this $25 free credit, you will first need to register your credit card with Google. But I'm not happy with the way apps are implemented. The play store is loaded with apps that are made for mobile phones, apps that require very detailed access to the device etc. Google still seem to have ignored some of the security enforcements on playstore. Also, there are usability issues with the OS. If you are watch ... ing some podcast/vieo and pause it for a while and the device 'sleeps', when you turn on the device again it will take you to the 'google now' screen and you will have to navigate to the app again to re-launch the video/podcast. On top of this, my podcast experience was tiresome, since when I re-launch the podcast app, it starts the video/audio from the beginning. Once the video stops, you are shown a blank screen and it will not auto navigate back to the menu/list. I will have to click on the back button. Some small usability features, but they matter a lot when you are hooked on to the device. On the positive, there are some apps that cost in Apple app-store vs the same ones available in Google Play store for free! If you are not planning to load too many apps, but want to load some of your personal videos/photos to the device, I would suggest you go for 8GB version and then buy Kingston wi-drive. You will get a 16GB version of wi-drive for under 60 bucks and 32GB version under 90 bucks at BH. You can load all your content on that device and then stream them wirelessly. expand » « collapse

My gripe with most tablets is that video playback was very choppy, and hard to maneuver around when going in and out of video mode. Not with this tablet. Simply perfect. As far as user experience, there are some pluses and minuses compared with other tablet, but you're simply not going to find an overall package as good as this.
Some areas, that could be better.
1. Sound is great, however, sound was better on the samsung 7' tab. 2. Expan ... dable storage. You'll learn to live without it though. 3. The black bars on the top and bottom. Wish there was a way to minimize the screen real estate, but you forget about it after a while.

I never found a tablet I wanted. I don't like closed systems (so apple is out), and Android tablets were always lacking something. Then comes along the Nexus 7. It is a pure Android experience, no overlays or anything added my manufacturers. The screen is absolutely gorgeous. It is a screamer (insanely fast). So easy to use and set up. You will be up and running within a few minutes of turning the Nexus 7 on. Quad core and 12 graphic p ... rocessors, 1 gig ram and 16gig storage all for less than $250.00. And if you are worried about not having an expandable storage slot, you can always use StickMount (free on Google Play) and use a USB Flash drive for all your movies and songs (or use the cloud...Google Music for all your songs and Dropbox for streaming movies).
Also, it comes with Adroid 4.1.1 (Jelly Bean), and it is pure Butter Smooth. You will not regret this purchase. It may be cheap, but it isn't junk... expand » « collapse

I bought it for my technophobe dad, and he loves it!!! It is amazing that he actually uses the tablet to initiate video chat with family, check mail, read news etc. That is a big deal, as he hardly uses his laptop and shies away from anything to do with a computer. The simplicity of the interface really helped him get used to the device very quickly.
Now, my kids who have two tablets(Ipad and Samsung) already are begging me to get one for them!!

The new jelly bean android os works flawlessly I love this tablet.
I got a nexus 7 for my fiance and she LOVES it, the OS is really nice, way cooler than iOS on my iPad. Its just the right size, maybe a little heavier than ideal, but hey I guess they did their best.

I was debating between a small tablet or smart phone, tablet won! It does every thing I wanted except make calls. Texting and skype and apps work great.

Cons: Adobe Is Un-downloadable
My husband bought the Nexus 7 for our daughters 6th birthday. She loves it and can download games herself. The only complaint that we have is that Adobe can not be downlaoded to the newest version. This causes her not to be able to watch somethings on the internet... like the Disney channel. But she loves it and it's hers!

Item.ReviewTitle: Great Gadget - worth every dollar spent
Item.Review:
Pros: Operating System; Web Browsing; Battery Life; Easy To Customize; Screen; WiFi; App Availablity; Weight Feel
Cons: Chrome Browser; Speaker not loud enough; Save For Offline Reading
considering Version 1 this is a pretty solid Tablet. However I wish some thing are available - More Storage space, Automatic Offline availability of Content - which you need to explicitly request on content, and in the browser - Save for offline reading option. However nothing beats some of the features like "(Cloud)Print to Tablet", Reading view on PDF docs, and games.

I have had this device for a little over two weeks and find myself using it every chance I get. At home I grab it to look up stuff on the internet or to read an ebook. The system is super fast and I really enjoy how easy it is to see what is running in the background and if necessary to close the program.
The only thing I wish it had is a video output.

Item.ReviewTitle: awesome for movies, reading (novels and currents) - replaced my kindle
Item.Review: Stopped using my kindle altogether (which I loved for its easy reading, no backlight), because its just such a pleasure to read Google Currents, Magazines (Wired and Popular Science look great on here), and even longer reading (Google Books, Amazon Kindle app).

I bought my father the Nexus 7 as a gift when it launched. He hasn't put it down since. He's using it to skype, email, watch foreign television he can't get on local channels, it's become an extension of him. His only wish is that he had the 3G version (it was sold out when I put my order in). Would highly recommend going for the upgrade.

Item.ReviewTitle: Love the size -- works very well
Item.Review:
Love this tablet. Bought it for my mom who's in her late 50's. She LOVES it and keeps emailing me from it to tell me as much. She and I have been video-chatting several times a week since I gave it to her. She doesn't have too many complaints other than wishing there was a separate hangouts app so she wouldn't have to find it from within Google+.
Good job Google and Asus.

A great tablet that is absolutely fantastic for reading books, news and browsing the web. Watching an HD movies on it is absolutely amazing :-). It fits in my back pants pocket so it is always on me! The battery is fantastic, lasts the whole day! The 8GB is more than enough for all the apps and games, although you might want to get the 16GB if you plan on downloading offline HD movies.
Item.HelpfulCount: 1 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.ReviewTitle: Really great tablet for a really great price
Item.Review: The Nexus 7 is the best electronics purchase I have made in a very long time. It's really amazing what you get for the price. Just take a look at the specs. It comes with the latest version of Android, Jellybean, which really refines the OS and adds some sweet features like Google Now (if you have an Android Smartphone with Jellybean, you will find it especially awesome). I use it primarily for browsing the web with Chrome which is a really nice web browsing experience, and seems much faster than my iPad. The size is perfect to fit in your hand and not too heavy to read a book. It's a great deal!

Perfect size, perfect casing, and with Android Jellybean, it's the perfect OS. Everything is buttery smooth and it looks amazing.
Only downside? Very low memory storage (8GB fills up easily after a few games and movies) and NO option for expandable storage. Why would you not have expandable storage when you only have 8 GB or 16 GB of storage space?!

I'm very happy with this tablet. The size is great for reading and surfing. I like the shape and the feel of the back. The screen is clearly not retina or anything but it works fine for me. I like the initial set up widgets that it comes with; all my media is splashed right up front. Only drawback is I use the Kindle app a lot so most of the books I read don't show up in the big widget.

Pros: Web Browsing; WiFi; App Availablity; Operating System
Cons: Difficult To Customize; Battery Life
would like to be able to have additional storage thru ubs or slot

Item.ReviewTitle: Good to lend to kids, with caveat
Item.Review:
The Nexus 7 is a good form factor (and a good price point, especially the 8GB version) for lending to your Angry-Birds-obsessed kids. I loaded it up with a Play Store gift card so that they have a budget for buying more ebooks (the $25 credit for buying the tablet initially was enough to cover all the games they wanted), and put a leather case on it in case they drop it and App Lock to keep them out of apps I don't want them using.
Be cautious about letting younger kids unplug the charger cable; if they are rough or confused about which direction to pull (straight out is apparently difficult for preschoolers to understand), it will no longer make good contact and mine now requires some careful propping to charge but is otherwise holding up perfectly.

I buy my nexus 7 few weeks ago, it cames protected in a box.the product was good, its not a PC or a laptop, but for web browsing, light games(compared to computer) and watching videos its a great device. its also help me in school as a note-pad.one thing bothers me alot - the screen glass is a litlle spongey in the left side. its not in all the devices but according to internt forums Im not the only one.

It is a grate buy Strong and fast The display is amazing, good for reading books, watching youtube or playing games. grate softwear as well, google really done it with the jellybean, amooth and sharp. a grate buy

Item.ReviewTitle: Great in a pinch or for short-term use
Item.Review: I use my Nexus 7 for short-term web surfing, watching videos, checking email, and for meeting notes and reminders, less so for music. Occasionally use it for GPS but GPS seems pretty flaky on it ie: works intermittently and I don't like leaving location or GPS services on, so have to remember to enable those when I use GPS. It beats carrying around a laptop or even an iPad for meetings or sitting around in waiting rooms. I'd not want to use it for a week-long trip, but I'm pretty internet-connected. For others, it may be just fine for that. There are apps for SSH / terminal access and Jabber, which I use for work. The RDP app is rather useless on a Nexus though. I was thrilled to learn it has a document reader that easily opens Microsoft documents (Word, etc.) If you use it for note-taki ... ng, I recommend getting a bluetooth keyboard case for it. expand » « collapse

Great product, but only one problem - it's too new. I could not find the camera app. Went to website - not very helpful. Took back to store - they couldn't find it right away. Took 30 minutes to figure it out. Product is so new that the documentation has not been fleshed out, yet.

Item.ReviewTitle: No ad hoc, great screen, fast
Item.Review: I use this for general web browsing and watching videos. The screen is crisp and the interface is responsive. Feels solid. However, ad hoc wifi is not available on this device, even after rooting it, so you can't tether it to a phone that can only do ad hoc networks.
Item.HelpfulCount: 1 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Review: I purchased the nexus 7 to use as an easily transportable device to use in my work as a hospital based emergency physician. I have had experience using the ipad 2 for a period of time, and have found it to be too large and bulky to easily carry around. The nexus 7 has impressed me with its feel, its speed, and the quality of its screen. For all practical purposes, the nexus 7 does everything that the ipad does (sure, sure, there are less apps available), does it quickly, efficiently, and with ease. Unfortunately, a 7 screen is not enough real estate for me to use professionally. Even with that being said, the nexus 7 is a solidly constructed, fast, and fun little tablet.

Item.ReviewTitle: Great Tablet at a great price
Item.Review: I use this product to surf, keep in touch with friends, E-Mail etc. Very intuitive android interface that runs very smoothly even when there are multiple applications open. A great purchase if you are looking for the latest tablet features without breaking the bank.

From all the other tablets i've used this one has to be the most fluid. Excluding the Ipad, but thats a whole different operating system on it. I like the fact that i can play games on it and do my work from school on it. The only negative i'd have to say is the lack of wifi. everyone complaining about storage space 16 gigs is plenty.

I was very enthusiastically looking forward to get my hands on my first android table but it was such a disappointment. First of all it took about a month for B&H to ship my order. After I got it, the first thing I checked for was the screen lifting issue and no surprise, mine had the same problem that many other people are still having with Nexus 7. Since I already knew it was a widespread issue, I was like OK, it's not a big deal. So I was fairly happy with my device until a couple of days later I noticed the screen is flickering and after doing a quick research I found out that it's also a know issue among almost all the units! Now I'm kind of thankful that I don't have the other problems that people are having with Nexus 7 such as touch screen not responding, spontaneous reboots, e ... tc. I might be returning this product to B&H during the 30 day period. expand » « collapse

Item.ReviewTitle: best tablet for size and money

Pros: Battery Life; App Availablity; Operating System; Easy To Customize; Web Browsing; Screen; WiFi
Being in sales this tablet is great for its compact size and features, along with millions of apps available to make it completely customizable

My tablet didn't suffer from any defects such as the screen lift problem that some users were reporting. It's incredibly fast, hardly ever lags and plays the most graphics intensive android games with out a hiccup.I was, at first, hesitant about getting a 7 tablet but the form factor is perfect. It is light and compact enough to take it everywhere without feeling inundated. The reason for the 4 stars is that the screen quality is not the best out there. The color saturation isn't as good as my Galaxy SIII. The colors just don't pop, but you can't expect all the bells and whistles for something at this price point. I use my tablet for reading, magazines, games (Dead Trigger, Radiant Defense), controlling my HTPC (Splashtop & Unified Remote), navigation (tethered to my phone), streamin ... g music (Pandora & Tune-In radio), recipes, and so much more. expand » « collapse

Its a great tablet and the 7 inch screen is perfect. And that screen, wow! If this would have been out when I got mine, I would have purchased the nexus. And of course, it would have come from B&H!
jelly bean is a great operating system, quick and responsive. i was apprehensive at first about getting a 7 inch tablet but it is very portable and i think preferable to a larger screen model

Some people complained that the screen was not screwed down securely, but I guess Asus has addressed this issue as mine is perfect. This product will open up a whole new set of opportunities, oh yes and you get a free movie, book and several magazines plus a 10 dollar credit when you sign up with Google Wallet.

I actually got this to simply keep at home and check my mail, surf, watch movies, and travel with. I have an Iphone and can do all the above with that as well, however let's be real, the screen is too small for some of those activities and well, the Nexus is actually the perfect size and buy for anyone looking to get a great tablet without breaking the bank. It's fast, fun, and all around a pretty, pretty cool device! Even though I'm a huge Apple fan - I've always been open to all gadgets and platforms and Android is one great platform! Besides, how can you not love that adorable Droid Robot!!! On an end note, congradulations to ASUS for manufacturing a really spify tablet for Google and congradualtions to Google for requiring high standards with an emphasis on affordability!
